description: Smallest positive Fibonacci number divisible by n.
comments: Corollary 1 in Riasat (2011), "every positive integer divides infinitely many Fibonacci numbers," demonstrates that this sequence is infinite. - _Alonso del Arte_, Jul 27 2013Note that F(0)=0 is divisible by any n>0, hence "positive" is added in NAME.- _Zak Seidov_, Jan 07 2016
references: Samin Riasat, "Z[phi] and the Fibonacci Sequence Modulo n" Mathematical Reflections 1 (2011): 1 - 7.
links: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..500
formula: a(A000045(k)) = A000045(k), for k > 0. - _Altug Alkan_, Jan 07 2016
example: Fibonacci(12) = 144 is the first that is divisible by 6, so a(6) = 144.
mathematica: With[{fibs = Fibonacci[Range[150]]}, Flatten[Table[Select[fibs, Divisible[#, n] &, 1], {n, 60}]]] (* _Harvey P. Dale_, Oct 20 2011 *)
prog: (PARI) a(n)=my(k); while(fibonacci(k++)%n,); fibonacci(k) \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Feb 04 2014
author: _J. Lowell_
extensions: More terms from _Patrick De Geest_, Jun 15 1999
